body:
I see this in the console output
```
WARNING: Delegated to the 'execute' command.
         This behaviour has been deprecated and will be removed in a future release.
         Please use the 'execute' command directly.
```

Perhaps `extensionContext.getExecutionException().isPresent()` is always false?
https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/766561f5884600ee91c1845c647c8ce21c7c38da/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/TempDirectory.java#L285C6-L285C6

Hi @delanym,

Thanks for raising the issue.

If you want us to investigate this, please provide a minimal sample application that we can run ourselves (preferably a public Git repository or a ZIP file attached to this issue).

There is no test failure in the above example.

When I run it, it prints:

```
/var/folders/_7/ll0c1sh52c5dfrvmq7j8l1x00000gn/T/junit13377456877063442804
```

And when I execute `open /var/folders/_7/ll0c1sh52c5dfrvmq7j8l1x00000gn/T/junit13377456877063442804`, I get the following:

```
The file /var/folders/_7/ll0c1sh52c5dfrvmq7j8l1x00000gn/T/junit13377456877063442804 does not exist.
```

Which indicates that the folder was deleted after successful completion of the test class.

> Perhaps `extensionContext.getExecutionException().isPresent()` is always false?

Now that we have verified your actual use case, I can answer this question.

Yes, I believe that's the case.

The team will need to investigate this to be certain, but I believe the following is the cause of this behavior.

The `ExtensionContext` for a class-level temp-dir (`static` field) will not return an execution exception thrown by a test method within that class. Consequently, the `CloseablePath` (created the for static temp-dir field) does not know that it should retain the temp-dir after a test method failure.

rename.to: `CleanupMode.ON_SUCCESS` for class-level `@TempDir` does not work for failure in `@Test` method

body:
I have tentatively labeled this as a bug and assigned it to the 5.10.1 milestone.

However, if the "fix" turns out to be non-trivial, we may decide to address this (if possible) in 5.11.
